abstract.para: This guide describes the administration of &slem; using Cockpit.

section.title: About Cockpit
section.para: Cockpit is a web-based graphical interface that enables you to manage most of the administration task from one place by using plugins. You do not need to create credentials for cockpit as by default Cockpit uses the same credentials that you use to login to your server. Cockpit uses APIs that already exist on the system without adding additional layer to your system.
Cockpit enables you to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: download container images and run containers
update the server
manage the server storage
inspect and change network settings
manage user accounts
view system logs
create and administer virtual machines
inspect and interact with &systemd; services
switching SELinux modes
use a terminal on a remote server in your web browser

section.title: Getting Cockpit
section.para: Cockpit is included in the delivered pre-built images, or can be installed if you are installing your own instances manually. For details regarding the manual installation, refer to .

Though Cockpit is present in the pre-built images by default, the plugin for administration of virtual machines needs to be installed manually. You can do so by installing the microos-cockpit pattern as described bellow. Use the command below as well in case Cockpit is not installed on your system.
Reboot your machine to switch to the latest snapshot.

note.title: Cockpit's plugins installed from the microos-cockpit pattern may differ according to technologies installed on your system
note.para: The plugin Podman containers is installed only if the Containers Runtime for non-clustered systems patterns are installed on your system. Similarly, the Virtual Machines plugin is installed only if the KVM Virtualization Host pattern is installed on your system.

section.title: Authentication
section.para: Cockpit enables you to log in directly to each machine that can expose the 9090 port. If the port cannot be accessed on the particular machine, you can still use Cockpit to administer the machine by using it as a secondary server. For a procedure of adding a server as secondary, refer to .

note.title: A limited count of secondary servers
note.para: The count of secondary servers that you can administer from one primary session is limited to 20. If you need to administer more servers, add other primary servers or use another tool for cluster administration.

section.para: To log in to the primary server, enter your credentials on the Cockpit login page. To log in to secondary servers, there are two options. You can access secondary machines after log in to the primary server, or you can access a secondary machine using the Connect to field on the login page.

section.title: Adding secondary servers
section.para: To add a server as a secondary, proceed as follows:

step.para: Log in to the primary server with an account with the system administrator role.
Click on the USERNAME@HOSTNAME in the left upper corner.
Fill in the host identification and optionally user name that will be used to log in to the server. You can assign a color to the machine. When the details are complete, click Add.
Verify a fingerprint on the server you want to add, if the fingerprint matches or if you have not set up the SSH connection, click Accept and connect to proceed.
Fill in the password and if needed check Automatic login. Cockpit will generate a new SSH key for the user and next time tou will be logged in automatically.

section.title: Logging into secondary servers directly
section.para: You can log in to any secondary server without logging in to the primary server first. This solution can be useful when you do not have credentials for the primary server. The primary server will be used as a bridge and you will be connected to the secondary server using SSH.

To connect to the secondary server, expand Other options on the login screen of the primary server. Fill in you user name, password and the IP address of the secondary server. If you try to log in for the first time, you are asked to verify the fingerprint, click Accept and connect.

section.title: System overview
section.para: The Overview page provides information about the health of your server, CPU and memory usage and also hardware details. On this page you can also change the host name, configure a system time and view SSH keys.
The Health part displays if your system is up-to-date or if there are any updates to install. Clicking the displayed statement takes you to the Software Updates. For details, refer to .

The Usage part gives CPU and memory usage. For detailed performance metrics, click View details and history. Clicking on mount points in Disks takes you to . Clicking on a particular service, opens the service details under .
In the Configuration part you can perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: change the host name by clicking edit and entering the required host name
change the system time by clicking on the date and time value. In the popup window select a time zone or set the time, either manually, or synchonize it with an NTP server.
view your SSH keys by clicking Show fingerprints.

section.title: &slema; logs
section.para: After clicking Logs, Cockpit enables you to view logs on your system. You can filter the logs according to the following criteria:

listitem.para: to filter the logs according to a specific time, you can choose from the following values:
the standard syslog severity levels are used (sorted from the most severe to the least):
The system is unusable. This is a panic condition.
This log requires your immediate action.
Failures in primary systems. You should correct the problem immediately.
Not an urgent error, but should be handled within a specific time.
Not an error, but indicates that an error might occur if no action is taken.
Unusal events that are not errors. No immediate actions are required.
Normal operational messages that serve as a confirmation that the system is working properly.
These messages are used just for debugging of the system.
You can filter logs for a particular service, daemon or process. Available identifiers are parsed from the logs currently displayed according to the set filters.
You can refine the logs view here according to the following criteria:
logs on the specified date or newer will be displayed. You can specify the time the following way:
using the absolute date in the format YYYY-MM-DD

using relative time by prefixing the value with - or + and specifying units. You can use the following units: s or seconds, min or minutes , hours or h, days or d, weeks or w, months or M, and years or y.
logs on the specified date or older will be displayed. You can specify the time the following way:
using the absolute date in the format YYYY-MM-DD

using relative time by prefixing the value with - or + and specifying units. You can use the following units: s or seconds, min or minutes , hours or h, days or d, weeks or w, months or M, and years or y.
enter an integer - 0 means the current boot, -1 is for the previous boot, 1 for the first boot, 2 for the second, etc.
specify a &systemd; unit which logs you want to display. Use one of the formats:

enter a string that you want to find in the log messages. You can also use PERL-compatible regular expressions. Alternatively, you can filter message according to message log fields, in the format: FIELD=VALUE, for example, CODE_LINE=349 displays logs with this value.

section.title: Managing storage
section.para: The Storage page enables you to monitor traffic on your drives, repartition your system, view storage logs and create RAIDs or LVM.

section.title: Monitoring data flow on disks
section.para: The graphs in the Storage page display reading and writing data flow to devices. Each device in the graph has a different color. After hovering over the displayed data flow peak, you can identify the device name.

section.title: Managing file systems
section.para: The Filesystems view enables you to create a partition table and to format or mount file systems. You can sort the mounted partition according to Name or Mount point. Click on the particular file system to open the details window.
To format the partition, click Format next to the particular partition description to open the format window.
You can specify the following details:

listitem.para: enter a unique name of the partition.
select the file system. BTRFS is mandatory for the / partition.
this is a mandatory option. Specify to which directory the partition will be mounted.

in the Custom mount options text field you can enter a comma-separated list of options. For common the options, refer to Filesystem Independent Mount Options. Those options are used in the options part of the /etc/fstab file.
select the encryption method or do not encrypt the partition. If you choose any of the encryption methods, the following fields appears:
enter a passphrase to unlock the encrypted partition.
the passphrase is stored in /etc/luks-keys and you are not asked for the passphrase on next boot.
you can pass a list of options described in supported encrypted options.

section.para: After you specify all required details, click Format to proceed.
If a partition is alread formatted, you can mount it by clicking Mount. Here you can change the mount point and mount options. To proceed, click Mount.

section.title: Software RAID managament
section.para: The Devices view enables you to add or manage RAIDs.

section.title: Creating RAIDs
section.para: You can create RAIDs of different levels on your system from the Devices parts by selecting the Create RAID device option in the hamburger menu.
Enter the following parameters of the RAID:

listitem.para: enter a unique name of the RAID.
select one of the following RAID levels:

data are split evenly to two or more disks. Such a solutions provides higher performance, because you can read data from several disks simultanenously, but does not provide any fault tolerance. You need to have at least 2 disks.
is a mirror. Data are kept in exact copies on several disks. If there is a failure on one disk, you can use data on another disk. Typically, this RAID level uses 2 disks.
provides striping and a dedicated disk for parity. You need to have at least 3 disks.
provides striping, the parity data are distributed on all disks. The minimum count of disks is 3.
provides striping and two parity blocks distributed across disks. The minimum count of disks is 4.
is a combination of striping and mirroring. Each stripe is mirrored to another disk. The minimum count of disks is 4.
is the size of chunks. A chunk is the minimum amount of data read or written to each data disk in the array during a single read/write operation.
select the disks that should be included in the RAID. The required amount of disks depends on the selected RAID level.

section.para: Confirm the parameters by clicking Create. The RAID then appears in the Devices part.

section.title: Modifying RAIDS
section.para: Click the RAID in Devices to open the RAID details view. In the detailed view you can stop or delete the RAID, add or remove disks and format the device.

With some RAID levels you can switch on the Bitmap option, that enables you to synchronize only the changes after a disk is temporarily disconnected. If the Bitmap is off, all data on a disk will be synchronized.

You can remove and add disks in the Disks part. After any change to the array, the system is undergoing resynchronization that might take some time. Keep in mind, that each RAID level requires a mimimum count of disks, therefore, Cockpit does not allow you to remove disks that are required by the particular RAID level.
The Content view enables you to create a partittion table (either MBR or GPT), format the disks and mount the RAID.

section.title: Logical volume mamagement
section.para: Using Cockpit you can create a thinly provisioned logical volumes or logical block devices. To do so, create a volume group of disks by selecting Create volume group in the hamburger menu in Devices.

Enter the volume group name and select disks that will be part of the volume group. Confirm the data with Create. The volume group appears in the Devices view. Now you can create a logical volume (either a block device or a pool of thinly provisioned volumes). To create a logical volume, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click on the volume group in Devices.
In the volume group details, click Create new logical volume
Specify a logical volume name, select either a block device or a pool of thinly provisioned volumes, and select size to use.
Click Create to confirm the details.

section.para: If you created a block logical volume, you need to format the volume by clicking Format and filling the details as described in .
If you created a pool of thinly provisioned volumes, you can create a thin volume by clicking Create thin volume.

Enter a unique name, select the size of the volume, and confirm by clicking Create. You can create several volumes of the particular volume group by clicking Create thin volume again. Format the volumes by clicking Format and filling the details as described in .
Other actions on a particular volume are available in the three-dots menu: Deactivate, Create snapshot or Delete.
Shrinking or growing a volume is available by clicking on Shrink or Grow in the particular volume details. These features are not available for all file systems and volume types.

section.title: Managing networking
section.para: After clicking Networking, you can view traffic on your system, manage firewall, manage network interfaces or view network logs.

section.title: Firewall

important.title: Firewall and Podman
important.para: Using firewall along with Podman may result in missing Podman-relateds firewall rules after reloading the firewalld service. Therefore, it is recommended to keep the firewall in its default setting (disabled) if you intend to use Podman.

note.title: The cockpit service is not included in the public zone
note.para: If you turn on the firewall, add the cockpit service to the public zone, otherwise the Cockpit web UI might be disconnected after the reboot.

section.para: The Firewall view enables you turn on the firewall, which is off by default. After turning it on, you can edit firewall rules and zones by clicking Edit rules and zones
To add a service to an existing zone, click Add services. Then select a service from the list and confirm with Add services.

If you need to define a zone on top of the currently available, click Add zone. In the Add zone window select the Trust level. Each trust level of network connections has a predefined set of included services (the Cockpit service is included in all trust levels). You can also allow addresses from the entire subnet within the particular trust level, or you can define a specific range of allowed IP addresses - as a comma separated list.

section.title: Interfaces
section.para: From the Interfaces part, you can add, modify or delete VLANs, bridges or bond interfaces.

section.title: Managing bonds
section.para: A bond interface is a combination of several network interfaces into one bond. Depending on the Mode (described further), network bonding can increase performance by increasing the network throughput and bandwidth. Network bonding can also increase fault tolerance by keeping overall connectivity even if some of the bonded interfaces stopped working. To add a bond interface, click Add bond.
Specify the following parameters of the bond interface:

listitem.para: enter a unique name of the interface.
select which network interfaces should be grouped to the bond.
You can either select a specific MAC address of the underlying interface, or you can use any of the following options:
use the permanent hardware address if the device has a MAC address.
during the bond activation the MAC address is not changed.
a random MAC address is created on each connection attempt.
creates a hashed MAC address.
Keep the default mode or select any of the following modes:
Transfers packets from the first available interface to the last. The mode offers fault tolerance and load balancing.
Only one interface in the bonding is active. If the active interface fails, the backup will be activated.
Balancing using a transmit hash policy. The default is a modulo device count. To select a different policy, specify the xmit_hash_policy option in the Option field.
Everything is transmitted on all interfaces.
Creates aggregation groups that share the same speed and duplex settings.
Is a channel bonding that does not require any special switch support. The outgoing traffic is distributed according to the current load on each interface.
Includes adaptive transmit load balancing and receive load balancing, no special switch support is required.
this selection is available only for the Active Backup mode. You can select a particular interface that will be used as primary, while other interfaces in the bond are used as secondary.
select the type of link monitoring.
specifies the interval in which the particular link monitor performs checks. The value is in ms.

define time in ms for how long the bond is disabled after a link has been activated. The value should be a multiple of the Monitoring interval value, otherwise it will be rounded to the nearest value. Available only for the MII link monitor.

define time in ms for how long the bond is disabled if a link failure has been detected. The value should be a multiple of the Monitoring interval value, otherwise it will be rounded to the nearest value. Available only for the MII link monitor.
specify a list of host IP addresses that you want to monitor. Available only for the ARP link monitor.

section.para: To modify or delete a bond interface, click on the particular bond name to open the details. There you can change the parameters of the bond described below.

listitem.para: select a MAC address from the list.
the bond connects automatically by default. Uncheck the box to disable the automatic connection.
after clicking edit, you can set IP adress and configure a specific DNS, DNS search domain and Routes.
after clicking edit, you can specify a particular value of maximum transmission unit in bytes.
after clicking edit, you can edit the same parameters as when you were creating the bond interface.

section.title: Managing bridges
section.para: A network bridge is a device that creates a single aggredated network from multiple networks. To create a bridge, click Add bridge
Specify the following:

listitem.para: specify a unique name of the bridge.
select interfaces to be included in the bridge

STP is a network protocol used for Ethernet networks that prevents bridge loops by setting a preferred link whenever network switches are connected with several links. This preferred link is used for all Ethernet traffic unless it fails. In that case a redundant link is used instead. For details regarding STP, see STP.
If you enable the STP protocol, then you can edit the following settings:
the lower the priority, the higher the probability of the switch to become the root switch.
specify the time spent in the listening and learning state (in seconds). The default value is 15 s, but you can use any value between 4 and 30 s.
specify the time between each bridge protocol data unit (BDPU) that is sent on a port (in seconds). The default value is 2 s, but the recommended range is 1 to 10 s.
specify the maximum length of time that passes before a bridge port saves its configuration BPDU information.

section.para: To modify or delete a bridge, click the bridge name to open the details.
There you can edit the following details:

listitem.para: the bridge connects automatically by default. To disable the automatic connection, uncheck the option.
after clicking edit, you can set IP address and configure a specific DNS, DNS search domain and Routes.
by clicking edit, you can edit all parametes of the bridge.

section.title: Managing VLANs
section.para: A virtual local area network is a logical subnetwork that groups devices from different physical LANs.
To create a VLAN, click Add VLAN and select the parent interface, assign an ID number and provide a name for the VLAN.
To modify or delete a VLAN, click the VLAN name.

section.title: Working with containers
section.para: After the first login to Cockpit, you need to start Podman. Keep the default check box selected to start Podman automatically on each boot.
The Podman containers page enables you to pull images from registries and manage your container. You can also filter the view by entering filter criterion into the filter field.

section.title: Getting container images
section.para: To start a container you need a container image. Click Get new image to open a search box for images.
In the search box:

listitem.para: choose preferred image registry or proceed with All registries
define the Tag. The default value is latest
fill in the image name or description.

section.para: Cockpit suggests possible images according to the entered name, registry and tag. Select the desired image and click Download.

note.title: Adding custom registry
note.para: &slema; comes with a predefined set of registries. If you need to use a custom registry, configure Cockpit to display them. Add the custom registry to the file /etc/containers/registries.conf to the registries list. For example, you can add registry.example to the list as follows:

tip.title: Pulling images using Podman
tip.para: You can also get container images using Podman by running the podman pull command.For details, refer to .

section.title: Managing containers
section.para: After you get an image, you can start a container based on that image by clicking the button next to the image information.
In the Run image window, enter the container details as described below.

listitem.para: You can define a custom name for the container. If not specified, the generated value is used.
defines a command that is run inside the container, for example, /usr/lib/systemd/systemd or /bin/bash
you can limit maximun memory consumption of the container by checking the box and specifying the limit
the container will not run in the detached mode

specify the weight of the container to use CPU time. The default weight is 1024. The weight applies only if containers are under high load. If tasks in one container are idle, other containers may use its CPU time.

If you have four contaners, two of them have CPU shares of 512 and the other two have 1024, then under high load the containers with lower CPU shares get only 16,5% of CPU time, while those with 1024 CPU shares get 33% of CPU time.

you can publish ports of the container to the host. If you do not provide the host IP address, the port will be bound to all host IP addresses. If you omit the host port number, a random port is assigned.
To publish a port for both protocols (TCP and UDP), enter the same port number twice just select different protocols.
maps volumes on the host system on paths in the container. The Container path must be an absolute path inside the container, if it does not exist, the directory will be created.
enables to pass environment variables to the container.

section.para: After expanding the container details, you can perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: access a terminal of the container in the Console tab
view the container logs in the Logs tab
delete the container by clicking the trash bin button
commit changes performed to the container, for exmple, installing packages to the container
start the container by clicking Start
restart the container, either by regular Restart, where processes running inside the container are stopped, or by Force restart, where the processes are killed and you might lose data

stop the container, either by regular Stop, or Force stop or by Checkpoint. When using Checkpoint the state of all processes in the container is written to the disk and after the next start, the container is restored to the same point before stopping.

section.title: Users administration

note.title: Users administration only for server administrators
note.para: Only users with the Server administrator role can edit other users.

section.para: Cockpit enables you to manage users of your system. Click Accounts to open the user administration page. Here you can create a new account by clicking Create new account or manage already existing accounts by clicking on the particular account.

section.title: Creating new accounts
section.para: Click Create new account to open the window that enables you to add a new user. Fill in the user's login and/or full name and password, then confirm the form by clicking Create.
To add authorized SSH keys for the new user or set the Server administrator role, edit the already created account by clicking on it. For details, refer to .

section.title: Modifying accounts
section.para: After clicking the user icon in the Accounts page, the user details view opens and you can edit the user.
In the user's details view, you can perform the following actions.

listitem.para: Click Delete to remove the user from the system.
By clicking Terminate session, you can log out the particular user of the system.
By checking/unchecking the Server administrator check box, you can assign or remove the administrator role from the user.
You can lock the account or you can set a date when the account will expire.
Click Set password to set a new password for the account.
By clicking Force change, the user will have to change the password on the next login.
Click edit to set whether or when the password expires.
You can add a SSH key for passwordless authentication via SSH. Click Add key, paste the contents of the public SSH key and confirm it by clicking Add.

section.title: Managing services
section.para: In the Services view, you can view status of &systemd; units, start resp. stop particular units and create &systemd; timers.

To manage a &systemd; unit, select the appropriate tab, then click on the particular unit. In the unit details you can view relations to other &systemd; units, the status of the unit, or you can perform the following actions that you can find under the three-dots menu:

listitem.para: Start if the unit is not running
Restart the running unit
Stop the running unit

Disallow running - that will stop the service permanently including its all dependencies. Keep in mind that the dependent service can be used by other unit and disallowing the unit might cause serious troubles to the system.

section.title: Creating new timers
section.para: To create a new timer, click Create timer in the Timers tab. Fill in the details described below in the opened Create timer window.

listitem.para: the name of the timer that will be used in the unit name and in the service unit name as well. For example, specifying the name: example will create the following unit files: /etc/systemd/system/example.timer and /etc/systemd/system/example.service
you can provide a short description of the timer
the command to be invoked when the timer is triggered

the timer can be triggered each time you reboot your machine or at a specific time. For the After system boot option, you can define delay of the service invocation. For the At specific time option, specify when the service should be invoked.

note.title: Overriding existings timers
note.para: The default set of &systemd; timers is stored in /usr/lib/systemd. If you create a timer with already existing names, the default unit file is not overwritten, but a new one is created in /etc/systemd/system/ that overrides the default unit file. If you want to restore the timer to the default one, delete the timer unit file in /etc/systemd/system/.
If you try to create a timer that already exists in the /etc/systemd/system/ directory, the unit file will be overwritten and the previous changes are lost.

section.title: Managing SELinux mode and policy
section.para: The SELinux tool enables you to switch between SELinux modes and view current modifications of the SELinux policy.

On &slema; SELinux is in the permissive mode by default. To temporarily switch to the enforcing mode, click the button with the Permisive label. Bear in mind that the change persist only to the next boot. If you need to perform persistent change of the mode, edit the configuration file /etc/selinux/config as described in .

The System modifications lists all modifications performed on the default SELinux policy. If you want to export the modifications and reuse them on different servers, click View automation script. In the new window you can copy a shell script or ansible configuration file that can be applied on other servers.

section.title: Managing &slema; updates and snapshots

important.title: No system updates without registering your system
important.para: If your system is not registered, the updates are not available and the check for updates fails. Therefore, register your system to view available updates. For details, refer to .

note.title: Snapshots and updates management only for system administrators
note.para: Only users with the Server administrator role can update the system or perform a rollback to another snapshot.

section.para: Cockpit enables you to update your &slema; instance or perform a rollback from the Software Updates menu.

section.title: Managing updates
section.para: Click Check for Updates to get a list of new package updates and patches available for your system. You can view each package update or patch information by clicking the blue icon next to the package update/patch. It is recommended to install the patches marked as important as soon as possible.

To apply the updates and patches, click Update and Reboot. The equivalent of the transactional-update up command is called and a new snapshot of your system is created. After the update completes successfully, your system will be rebooted and the new snapshot set as default.

You can postpone the reboot of your system after the update process by selecting Update without Reboot from the three-dots menu. Bear in mind that you need to reboot the system to activate the snapshot with updates. If you perform further changes without rebooting the system beforehand, a new snapshot will be created from the same point as the snapshots with updates. Therefore, the new snapshot will not include the updates.
You can also update &slema; using CLI. For details, refer to .

section.title: Performing rollbacks
section.para: In Snapshots & Updates you can perform a rollback to one of older snapshots by clicking Rollback and Reboot, or Rollback without Reboot in three-dots menu.

After rebooting the system, the snapshot you rolled back to will be set as active. Do not make any changes (install updates, packages, etc.) before rebooting your system, as the snapshot you rolled back to is not active. Any changes performed before you reboot your system will start from the currently active snapshot.
For a system rollback procedure performed using CLI, refer to .
